review_title: Best career move I have ever made!
job_title: Chief Information Security Officer in Madison, WI
pros: Exceptional team!  I have the room to maneuver toward the right solutions.  My peers inspire me and challenge my team to do great things.
cons: This is a State agency with politics at every turn.  Doing more with less is the noise before defeat.  Resource challenges eventually drive the best toward other adventures.

job_title: Grad Student Teaching Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: For a 50% appointment (equals 20 hr/week), the pay ($2000 USD/month) from my department is not too bad. The rate is continuously increased, albeit slowly and slightly, each year thanks to the TA union's strong and persistent organized efforts. You don't usually have to work to 20 hours.
cons: TAing while doing your own research/taking courses/reading can be a time sucker. If the TA monthly stipend is your only source of income, you won't go hungry but your savings don't go up either.

review_title: Great research institution, good benefits, maybe not for everyone
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Madison, WI
pros: Nice campus, always adding new facilities, cutting edge research, good health insurance, great location if you like outdoor activities, bike friendly campus and city, flexible work schedule (your mileage may vary)
cons: Location - far from larger cities.  Pay is not very competitive and does not seem to keep pace with the cost of living, expensive to park on campus, bureaucracy that comes with a large university

review_title: Great science in a fantastic city
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Many of the labs are at the top of the field, but without the pretense of a number of other top-10 schools.  Understanding, friendly faculty, staff, and peers. Recruiters come to this campus to draw from new talent pools.  Makes the job search much less stressful.
cons: No different from any other grad school experience.  You have to be willing to cope with many months of failure.  You have to be very self-motivated.  Etc.

pros: The benefits and paid time off are incredible.   It's hard to find an employer that offers more time off then working for the state.
cons: The pay tends to be lower then the private sector for obvious reasons.  Since we are funded in part with tax payer dollars raises are scarce.

pros: Great, friendly coworkers. Most people are always willing to help. I enjoyed going to work every day and always looked forward to projects and working with coworkers.
cons: Too many employees, a lot of wasted manpower. Way too much administration. There are too many workers doing the job an individual or a few people could do.

pros: Great learning environment, and people in management really know a lot and care about what they're researching and/or teaching. It's great to work with such talented and knowledgeable people. Great town for young people and night-life.
cons: A lot of the labs are old and outdated and we don't always have access to the best equipment. A job here would definitely be temporary as long as you don't mind living in a young, college town.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: University of Wisconsin-Madison is a very nice research university. It has many nation-famous areas, strong faculty members and good research atmosphere.
cons: The economy in Wisconsin is getting worse so the investment from the state is declining. The university becomes less attractive to young and talent assistant professors and graduate students

pros: Certainly the health care benefits are second to none and the opportunity to complete graduate level education while working to pay for it is very attractive.
cons: The benefits are exceptional, but with the combined load to school and work responsibilities, expect 60+ hour weeks with little semblance of academic breaks.

pros: Good benefits. Prestigious institution. Good colleagues.
cons:
Graduate School/Arboretum Administration is limited in vision, overly bureaucratic, abusive, controlling, vindictive, micromanaged.  Superlative achievement is not rewarded or supported.
Culture of fear. Cultural creatives attracted by aura and legacy of Aldo Leopold and others, only to be sucked dry, dispirited or tossed aside. Woefully underfunded, staff under-compensated.

review_title: UW has been an incredible place to work!
pros: Beautiful campus, welcoming community, progressing environment, surrounded by people wanting to learn, very collaborative work atmosphere, great networking opportunities.
cons: Winter. Honestly, I can't think of much else. Sometimes politics makes things challenging here but overall I couldn't ask for a better place to work.

job_title: Student Technical Support in Madison, WI
pros:
- Best campus in Wisconsin in terms of atmosphere and student body diversity
- Some absolutely wonderful people to work with!
- Decent benefits/salaries, solid flexibility... depending on the department
cons:
- Some people working on campus are simply there because they don't want to retire (which slows processes down, esp. when it comes to technology)
- Certain departments have small budgets and very little flexibility
- Few chances to move up in the workplace; this is due to budgets for the most part

review_title: Great place for chemistry graduate school!
job_title: Chemistry Graduate Student in Madison, WI
pros: Work-life balance, prestigious program without the cut-throat environment, helpful PIs and great relationships with academia and industry
cons: None I can think of.  UW-Madison is really a great place to get a chem PhD with respect to other top programs in the USA.

review_title: University of Wisconsin Soil Science- Software Development
pros:
Cutting edge soil and ag research used by real farmers to make real decisions.
Laid back environment, jeans are considered dressing up by soil scientists.
Supportive of work-life balance
Real software development and within a research environment, best of both.
Great if you are an environmentalist.
cons: Not always on cutting edge of software technology.   Farming community isn't as advanced as university researchers in terms of software technology.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Some state of the art research facilities - I performed Nuclear Materials research and the microscopy facilities available are very useful.
cons: Some advisors in the EP department are a little more hands-on and have been known to make grad student life more demanding - choose your graduate professor wisely.

pros: Very collaborative environment and "Midwest nice" people. Training is thorough and excellent.  Major focus on students and rigorous scientific training. Very competitive to get in, but once in, one is taken care of and given what is needed to thrive.  Very resource rich (all 1's on federal grants for environment)
cons: Standard academic bureaucracy. Not much support if not self-funded or after funding runs out. Postdoctoral voices in representation minimal but growing. State support minimal.

review_title: Division of Information Technology - Good place, but a bit behind on development practices
pros:
- Excellent work life balance 
- Training budgets are standard and expected to be used
- Relaxed atmosphere
cons:
- Under staffed (everyone seems to need more people)
- Slow to adopt new tools/technologies (lots of steps just to get something blessed)
- Behind on development practices (CI, Testing, etc)
- Practices vary wildly from group to group (make sure you ask!)

pros:
Flexible schedule - you create your hours.  

Primarily accountable to yourself, which is great if you work well on your own but it can be difficult if you enjoy team atmospheres and need someone to manage your productivity.
cons:
Work expectations are high.  Everyone assumes that you will be working over the weekend so it is difficult to develop a reasonable work-life balance.  

Really low pay - especially for the productivity demands. 

Competitive atmosphere among peers.

review_title: Great place to live and work
pros: Reasonable healthcare, WRS for retirement, vision care, ample vacation and sick leave, friendly environment, great city to live in, exciting research environment- very well funded in many different departments, open collaborative environment.
cons: Relatively low salary- but that's to be expected when you work for the state. A research assistant requires a Master's degree but only makes $35.343.

pros:
Cutting edge research, fun work environment, meaningful purpose for research.  Good experience on top of coursework.

I spent much of my last two years in college as working part-time in a research lab on campus.  The pay was decent for an hourly wage for a full-time student, and it was truly unique work.
cons: Adds onto hours spent for class, depending on PI it can be stressful, wet bench work can be frustrating when procedures go wrong.

review_title: Graduate Research Assistant at UW - Madison
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros:
- Excellent place to do doctoral studies with various opportunities to pursue interdisciplinary research.
- State of the art research facilities. 
- Highly motivated, skilled and extremely talented peer-group.
- Safe place to work late nights and even walk back home.
- Beautiful campus and city 
- One of the best downtowns.
- College football and basketball
cons:
- Winter, though not so much once you get used to it.
- Campus parking is a little expensive.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: The professors here are usually quite nice, and are willing to help out anything relate to the course. Most students are also nice and great to work with.
cons: Winter here in Madison is cold and not for everyone, and the city is relatively small, so not a whole lot to do compare to living in big cities. Salary is not great, and depending on the class, the teaching might take up a lot of time.

pros: The higher-ups really care about the work they're doing, and they're willing to accommodate everyone so we succeed.
cons: There are no downsides, really! I can work as little as 5 hours per week, so there's no stressful demand, and my bosses have been very helpful getting me situated in my position.

pros: Great community and a great to place to work.
cons: If only they could keep up even with base cost of living, and reset salaries to be competitive in the current market.  In over 5 years, all I ever saw were pay cuts and benefits cost sharing increases, as well as increases in responsibility as staff positions were eliminated.

review_title: I am not sure my boss knows my name after 2 years
pros: Flexible work schedule is possible for some employees.
cons: No salary increase, or even a review for 2 years.  Job duties are much different than led to believe during interview process.  Pretty sure my boss still does not know my name (School of Public Health).  Parking is 1/2 a mile away, and costs over $1000/year.  Cost goes up for parking, while salary is stagnant.

review_title: Great place -- same problems as with most higher ed institutions
pros: Very friendly and enriching environment.  Small-town feel with exceptional research resources. Depending on the research group, work expectations were overall very reasonable especially compared to other institutions I have worked at.
cons: As a postdoc without independent funding I had less autonomy than I felt I should have had. Partially my own fault, but also a more systematic problem that is not isolated to UW Madison.

review_title: Supportive community of graduate researchers and faculty
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Fun social atmosphere for graduate students. It's perfectly acceptable to work a normal 40 hour week, grab beers with students/faculty in the evening, and take a few weeks of true vacation throughout the year.
cons: Pay isn't very competitive, but it's not horrible considering cost-of-living.

pros: Very good place to advance research career. The University of Wisconsin Madison is a research based institute with a rank of second for research funds among public universities in the US. It has a beautiful campus and has a top rank for having the happiest students.
cons: The only cons is the lengthy cold winter. However, there is a strong transit network within the campus. The university is not very diverse compared to its peers.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros:
Top school and top quality people/professors. Great city, don't be fooled by its size, it has a lo to offer.
If you are a student with a family, then this is an excellent place.
cons: Some office politics and some professors can be manipulative.

review_title: Reasonable when needed to pursue a degree.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Provides teaching experience necessary for advancement in academic fields. Flexible hours. Reasonably good benefits. Tuition remission for graduate school.
cons: Hours predictably exceed limits set by appointment percentage. Salary is borderline poverty level. Continuing job opportunities at the institution hinges on the moods of legislators and the politics of university funding.

pros: UW is a top Academic Research/Teaching Facility providing ample opportunity to interact with  exceptional faculty and staff across the full spectrum of scientific and engineering research.
cons: Due to outside fiscal contraints salary/benefits as well as employment opportunities are waning but I anticipate that in time the citizens of the state of Wisconsin will realize the tremendous social and economic benefits conferred by a strong university system and will vote accordingly.

pros: This was the greatest college job ever.  I met all of my best friends there, enjoyed every moment and work, and it completely made my college experience.  I am complimented on my public speaking skills and ability to think on my feet to this day. I'd recommend it to anyone.
cons: Honestly, nothing. It was the best!

review_title: Scout is basically a scam at the taxpayer's expense
job_title: Senior Software Developer in Madison, WI
pros: Scout is fine is your idea of work is scamming a government grant trying to appear to do work rather than actually doing anything that works.
cons: Ed Almasy is a nightmare to work with. He comes in for a few hours on Fridays. He's milking a government grant with no supervision and nothing to show for millions of dollars in funding. The so-called software they produce to index STEM resources is done by hand like Yahoo back in the 1990s but should be automated by technology.

review_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant (Materials Science and Engineering), UW-Madison
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: World-class research institution. Madison is a great city to live in.
cons: Graduate student stipends are typically lower than similar universities in comparable towns to Madison. The cost of living has gone up in Madison over my time living here, whereas the stipends have not increased accordingly.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Madison is a great town to spend several years in. 3 seasons of good weather, good and diverse restaurants, lots of culture for a city it's size. And the University of Wisconsin is a top class university.
cons: The winters can be pretty terrible if you are not a cold and snow person. Wisconsin is a large university, so it can be hard to be a little fish in a big sea.

pros:
Professional Development Funds
Nice and friendly people
cons: Do NOT value employees! All talk and no actions! All about valuing employees but they know nothing! There's high status and low status employees. There's nothing in between.  The gap of pay is $20K.

review_title: Academic Staff are not valued by this employer.
job_title: Senior Research Specialist in Madison, WI
pros: Academic staff function in an intellectually stimulating workplace.
cons: Academic Staff are treated poorly and have no recourse.  The University negotiated in poor faith with unions and there has been systematic removal of compensation (benefits and salary).  I have witnessed a consistent lack of enforcement of equal employment opportunity laws.  Academic staff are pressured to work long hours and forgo leave benefits. I have experienced constant pressure against healthy work family balance.

review_title: Working in the Department of Continuing Studies was mundane at best.
pros: I do feel that, in working here, I learned a lot about web development. Unfortunately, that didn't stem into anything exciting, as I was required to execute the same tasks day in and day out.
cons: Limited room for growth, due to constant flux of employees. There is no heart in this building, but I don't know if that's useful information for you.

review_title: A good place for interesting part time work while in school.
job_title: Associate Instructional Specialist in Madison, WI
pros: Fellow staff are excellent, frank, & professional.  Compensation is decent for part time employment, & there is much informal learning & growth that can happen on the job.
cons: Training is very lacking in the associate instructional specialist realm. Some administrators do almost nothing & attempt to pawn off their simple duties on those who do not get paid for them

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Madison, WI
pros: Benefits packages like healthcare are great, lots of vacation and sick leave available.  Physicians are devoted to clinical research.  Atmosphere on campus is great, especially when school is in session.
cons: No training programs are in place for new employees.  Hard to move up within the University unless you have worked there for a long time.  Salaries are low and hard to live on in the city.

pros: The hours were very flexible, and there were a lot of opportunities to advance your existing skill set. Great experience working with people who have worked much deeper in the industry than this job. Good networking, as well.
cons: The university's control of their public image rules over everything, so creative, edgy, and hard-hitting ideas are almost always shot down.

pros: Projects were interesting and contributing to the progress of science is intrinsically rewarding. Individual contributions were stongly valued. Flexible working styles are accommodated.
cons: Working as a part of a small lab is like working at a small company. It can be rewarding and exciting at times when the science is going well, and the group mood can change quickly when there are issues with equipment and experimental trajectory.

review_title: I have a great job, but the workplace could use some improvement

I get to travel a lot

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI

pros: It is a good university with diverse studying areas encouraging and inspiring you to dig more and deeper in your area. The atmosphere here is happy.

review_title: Supportive environment, but lots of work
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI

cons: Depending on your professor, you may or may not get too much direction on what/how to teach. Completing MS in engineering often takes 2-2.5 years with other responsibilities (e.g. teaching, research).

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Madison, WI

pros: Great laboratory directors and cutting edge technology make this a dream job.  You are always learning something new, sometimes out of necessity and sometimes just for the fun of it.
cons: The only downside to this job is the pay, but that is understandable as it is a fellowship and not a career position.  Also, in academia, this isn't too bad of a salary.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Nice people all around you. Big campus with diversity and great sports. Excellent engineering school and Medical school which provide tons of research opportunities.
cons: Stipend is low relative to the living cost in Madison. The campus is huge and takes time to go from one building to the other.

job_title: IS Technical Services Senior in Madison, WI
pros: Above market pay for entry-level staff
cons:
Awful pay for intermediate or advanced staff
Poor room for advancement
Poor training and professional development opportunities
Horrible bosses

pros: As a research assistant you get to chose your own hours and work when you want. Professor was very easy to work with and helpful.
cons: There really aren't many cons to this position. It is flexible hours and a decent part time salary for a student.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: it really depends on the lab you are working, but overall Madison is a great place to live with reasonable living expense. The campus is petty beautiful. As it is a large research oriented university, you get to have a chance to collaborate with other labs/ departments.
cons: If you are from west (which is I am), the freezing winter weather was something I found hard to bear.

review_title: It is a great place to learn how to balance your work.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Madison, WI

cons: They pay you really little. The compensation level is so low so you have to learn how to manage your money well.

pros: I really enjoyed working for the UW as an employee in one of the IRIS offices. Supportive coworkers, a laidback work environment, and understanding supervisors/bosses, plus plenty of opportunities for networking within the field.
cons: Sometimes communication was not always clear or direct. Training was not thorough for my position, although it was part-time.

review_title: Gained lots of very valuable experience around tons of smart people
pros: Smart people, beautiful campus, decent salary, good location, very friendly and helpful staff when you need them, lots of great campus resources available, booming student life
cons: Wisconsin weather can get very cold at times, downtown Madison doesn't really compare to the rest of big city downtown areas

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
pros: Nice Environment. This is a big campus. There are many Multi-discipline research going on. People are very friendly. Good life work balance.
cons: Very cold in winter. Also there are not much going on in Madison. The salary is very low . The cost of living is relative high. The ta suffers here since there are some many student and classes.

pros:
Works with your schedule
Flexible hours
Understanding
Good work internment
Schedules around your exam schedule
cons:
Low pay
Not clear job description
Hours being cut due to university cutbacks
Can only work 20 hours a week.

review_title: Avoid if you are in science or research
pros: People are generally nice, most of us try our best to help each other. Decent vacation benefits.they do provide heathcare.
cons:
Where to begin. The university is declining quite rapidly. The biggest issue is that scientific staff are treated like garbage by the University as a whole, and the salary you will receive is commensurate with that. Not surprising as the number of science staff has dropped in half, while the administrative budget has somehow ballooned 500%. The university seems to want to invest in administrators and office staff, and pay them twice what the scientists and researchers make, even though the science staff are the ones working long hours to bring money back to the university in the way of grants. What is worse is that the chancellor, numerous deans and execs seem to be proponents of this model, that way they can continue to justify to the state why they need more state funding. Since 99% of science staff are paid from fed grants, it only makes sense to double the salaries of those paid from state funds.

They are implementing a new HR system going on 4 years now, which will further increase the inequity between the doers ( scientists), and the takers(office staff). Most of us can't wait for that.  Science staff have zero representation, unless you consider a secretary or dept administrator with a degree in email sending "representation". There is zero transparency here. If you want a raise, or promotion, good luck. HR has made sure to hide what it wants, so that fewer people can get raises/promotions, unless of course you are in HR and administration, then you know how to do it and are assured a good raise every year. 

Where else outside a major metro area can you be charge 1K a year to park 3 blocks from work? 

It is a major academic institution, so obviously there are ZERO education benefits. The University offers nothing in the way of tuition discounts for employees. Want to earn more education?, better get your checkbook out.

If you are looking to do science or research, and make a living, go somewhere else. This is not the place.

review_title: The MSC is the best place I've ever worked
pros: Great environment, progressive staff, and supportive interns all around. The Multicultural Student Center supports students of color wholeheartedly in ways that the University as a whole cannot because it's afraid to.
cons: The rest of the University outside of the 2nd floor of the Red Gym, is absolutely atrocious and is a facade of what it advertises as the "Wisconsin Idea"

review_title: I enjoyed working for the University as an academic coach by helping students grow and learn.
pros: The bosses are reasonable with employees who are working their way through school. There is room for advancement and increased salary. My coworkers were friendly and outgoing.
cons: The starting pay is low. Some of the training and protocol is excessive, which wastes time because it is mandatory before you start working.

review_title: Policies not family friendly but people are
pros: Surrounded by smart people, beautiful location, lots of opportunities for professional development
cons: Policies on family leave are severely lacking. Will say a lot about how much they support you...but when it comes to leave, pto, flex time, etc you will have no official support and only the mercy of your manager to fall back on.

pros: Great mission. good hours, substantial research support, progressive culture/history, a  beautiful campus, loyal alumni, good benefits and the memorial union.
cons: Shifting administrative priorities, overly combative faculty culture, variable student quality, lack of diversity, high outstate tuition and overemphasis on athletics, especially football.

pros: Of course, in research, it all depends on who's lab you're in.  In my experience though, the benefits are good, the work/life balance is very good, and the city of Madison is a wonderful place to live.  At the university, I'm constantly in touch with competent, friendly peers.
cons: Pay's not great but that's just the nature of research at this level.

review_title: Dull students, lack of academic air

HUGE gap in academic level between undergraduate & graduate bodies.
Very hard to find smart, intellectually challenging people (as the majorities are undergrad).
The campus is the downtown of the city, it is pretty crowded, parking space is not assigned to even professors.
TA workload is HUGE as compared to other research schools.

review_title: smart people, great city, fantastic benefits
job_title: Student Services Coordinator in Madison, WI

review_title: Overall, has been a great experience!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Madison, WI
